text.p: These are the leading stories in the Turkish press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- The Islamist Welfare Party says in a party report that passage of the secularist education bill would undermine domestic peace and incite anarchy.
- Turkey, Kazakhstan, Azerbaijan, Georgia and some leading American oil companies will form a consortium for an oil pipeline project between Baku and the Turkish Mediterranean port of Ceyhan.
- A deputy from the conservative opposition True Path Party, expected to opposed the secularist education bill, says he will vote in favour of the draft law.
- The energy ministry announces new regulations limiting natural gas price rises imposed by municipalities to 45 percent.
- Four leading commercial chambers will provide 800 school classes as a contribution to the new secularist education plans.
- The former Islamist-led government employed 280 people to work at the directorate of state archives without tests or security checks.
- Five prisoners escaped from Umraniye prison in Istanbul.
- Prime Minister Mesut Yilmaz says 1,000 trillion lira will be necessary in 1997 to bridge the social security deficit.
- Yasar Holding pulls out of the textile sector, selling a subsidiary to Izmir-based Ege Sokteks.
- Tyre manufacturer Petlas begins test production of tyres for F-4 and F-16 aircraft.
